RESTRUCTURING 
During 2010, AEGON went through a period of further restructuring, aimed primarily at reducing costs, improving 
returns and sharpening the company’s focus on its core growth markets. Regrettably, this restructuring led to the loss 
of just under 1,000 jobs, mostly in the United Kingdom, the United States and to a lesser extent the Netherlands. 
AEGON took specific measures to limit the number of compulsory redundancies and to help those who lost their jobs 
find alternative employment, either within the company or outside. 
 
United	 Kingdom	
 
Restructuring Withdrawal from UK bulk annuities market (complete). 
Sale of AEGON’s third party pension administration business (sale agreed) 
Closure of employee benefits business (complete). 
Sale of healthcare division belonging to UK subsidiary Origen (sale agreed) 
Further cost reduction measures, including restraints on recruitment (in process).
Business objectives To reduce costs, increase returns and further improve efficiency (objective to 
reduce costs from AEGON’s UK life insurance and pension businesses by 25% by 
the end of 2011). 
To focus on growth opportunities in key At Retirement and Workplace Savings 
markets.
Employees affected In 2010, AEGON reduced its workforce in the United Kingdom by 469. This figure 
includes positions lost as a result of both restructuring and natural attrition. 
Measures taken, where 
possible, to limit number of 
compulsory redundanciesAll other, non-payroll options for cost savings explored and, where possible, 
implemented. 
Staff redeployed to other departments. 
Other restraints imposed on payroll costs, including recruitment and salary freezes.  
Employees offered voluntary redundancy packages.
Measures taken to support 
employees affected by 
redundancyCareer transition program for all employees affected, provided by outside 
specialist. 
Additional training on interview techniques. 
All new positions advertised internally. 
All employees at risk of redundancy placed on a special redeployment register and 
provided with weekly updates of new job opportunities within the organization. 
Where appropriate, certain roles ring-fenced for employees at risk before being 
opened up to other candidates. 
Redundancy terms maintained for the duration of the restructuring program. 
Internal communications and 
consultation proceduresCommunications steering group established to ensure coordination of all internal 
and external communications. 
Significant internal communications program to minimize uncertainty for UK 
employees. 
Communication workshops for all line managers. 
Extensive consultations with UK trade unions, Aegis and Unite, on every proposed 
redundancy, to meet requirements of Recognition Agreement with unions and UK 
employment legislation. 
At least two face-to-face meetings with employees affected. Employees could 
choose to be accompanied by either a colleague or union representative. 
Open Q&A sessions with senior management. 
Increase in frequency of staff engagement surveys to improve employees’ 
understanding of company strategy (at the start of the program, 85% of staff said 
they understood the need for restructuring). 
Where possible, employees informed of all measures at the same time, or before, 
public announcements.
